Our investigation into regional climate patterns was supported by data obtained from the Global Historical Climatology Network (GHCN), covering temperature and precipitation records from numerous weather stations worldwide.
In order to understand trends in household income disparity, we employed data from the U.S. Census Bureau's Current Population Survey (CPS), focusing on annual income distributions from 2010 to 2020.

The study's findings on biodiversity loss were derived from analyses of the International Union for Conservation of Nature's (IUCN) Red List database, encompassing species populations from various ecosystems.
We examined patterns of consumer behavior using transactional data sourced from Nielsen's Retail Measurement Services, which tracks purchasing trends across a wide range of retail outlets.
To investigate the efficacy of vaccination campaigns, we analyzed immunization coverage data provided by the World Health Organization's (WHO) Global Vaccine Action Plan (GVAP) database.

Our study on traffic congestion relied on traffic flow data collected by the Department of Transportation's National Traffic and Highway Safety Administration (NTHSA) from sensor networks installed on major highways.
In order to assess the impact of deforestation, we utilized satellite imagery data from the European Space Agency's (ESA) Sentinel program, monitoring changes in forest cover over time.
To understand trends in educational attainment, we analyzed data from the UNESCO Institute for Statistics (UIS), which compiles global education statistics from national sources.
The investigation into disease outbreaks was supported by epidemiological data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's (CDC) Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report (MMWR) database.
Our study on economic inequality drew on income distribution data from the World Bank's World Development Indicators (WDI), providing insights into disparities across countries and regions.
We examined patterns of internet usage using data from the Pew Research Center's Internet & Technology division, which conducts surveys on digital behavior and online trends.

Our research on urbanization patterns utilized population density data from the United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs (UN DESA), offering insights into global demographic shifts.

The study's findings on food insecurity were based on household survey data collected by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), assessing access to nutritious food across different regions.
In order to understand patterns of wildlife migration, we analyzed tracking data from the Movebank database, which aggregates movement data from various animal tracking studies.

To assess trends in agricultural productivity, we utilized crop yield data from the United States Department of Agriculture's (USDA) National Agricultural Statistics Service (NASS), providing insights into crop performance over time.
